text:
Hi guys, I'm Laura Vitale and on this episode
of Laura in the Kitchen I want to share with

you a really delicious and simple marinade
that you can make for the entire Spring and

Summer season, it is what I call my Greek
chicken marinade.

You can do this on chicken thighs, you can
do this on chicken breast, you can do this

on shrimp, you just wouldn't want to marinate
the shrimp or any kind of fish for a long

time because there's acid so you want to marinate
it for 5 to 10 minutes and then go ahead and
pop it on the grill.

But it would be delicious, I'm going to share
with you chicken breast today because it happens

to be what I have on hand, this works just
as good if not better with boneless skinless
chicken thighs.

So let me run you through the list of ingredients,
it's very short and sweet, kind of like me,

you need your chicken breast of course, I've
got about a pound and a half, make sure they're

not too thin or otherwise, too thin they'll
dry out, too thick they won't cook all the
way through evenly.

Then here I've got dried oregano, dried basil,
and some dill weed, I've got lemon, garlic,

Dijon mustard, fresh chopped dill, and I've
got some onion, you also need red wine vinegar,
you need some olive oil, and some salt.
So, let's get going.

I'm going to use my mortal and pestle here
because what I want to do is I want to grind

up my dried herbs because there's so much
of it, if I don't then I feel like you get

really dry pieces of the herbs on the outside
of the chicken and it's not really pleasant
to me.

But if this doesn't bother you, then you can
skip this step.
What I do is I kind of grind it up in here.

Just till it's about half, see it's like really
really coarse?

I want half of it to be almost pulverized,
then the other half can stay pretty whole.

That is what I want, and what's really amazing
as well, when you do this with any ind of

dried herbs and spices, it brings them to
life, it almost like opens them up, it smells

outrageously good in here and all we did is
grind up my basil, oregano and dill weed.
But that is what I want, pop that in there.

Now, for the garlic and the onion, I don't
want chunks of this because I don't want this

to burn on the grill, and I also kind of want
that to be part of the marinade, so I use

a coarse grater, and I just grate them in
there.

You can just chop them really finely by hand,
it's fine, no worry, I use two cloves of garlic

for a pound and a half which is pretty garlicky
but I feel like that's sort of like what makes
it, you know what I mean?

I've never been to a Greek restaurant and
not had a very garlicky anything, like everything
is super garlicky which is what I like.

And then I take a half of a small onion and
I do the same thing, I kind of just grate
it right in there.

Add your Dijon mustard and your fresh chopped
dill.
Whoo!
My eyes are like on fire.
And then you need lemon juice.
You need lemon juice and red wine vinegar.
Combo of both is what makes this so good.
Along with some extra virgin olive oil.

Use regular olive oil or extra virgin whatever
you fancy.

And like I said, this would be equally if
not more delicious on chicken thighs.
Just saying.

Plus, boneless skinless chicken thighs are
half the price and twice the flavor of chicken
breast, so always keep that in mind.

It just happens to be what I have on hand
and you know me I waste nothing.

And whatever you see is what we eat here on
Laura in the Kitchen so when mamma's got fresh

chicken breast on hand, that's what I'm gonna
use.

I'm going to add a good pinch of salt that
way it's got a good chance for the salt to
really marinate the chicken.

This is the thickness of the breast, you see
I would say they're about a half an inch thick,

maybe a little bit bigger maybe about an inch
thick.

Any thicker than that, then I feel like they
wouldn't cook properly, and any thinner they
would just dry out.
Coat that in that really beautiful marinade.

And I am just going to pop this into the fridge
for several hours.

Like I said if you were doing this with fish,
which is delicious on shrimp or any sturdy

fish that you can grill, you just would not
want to do this for hours, you would want

to do this for maybe ten minutes, otherwise
the acid would cook your fish and it would

turn into ceviche which is delicious but not
the point of this.

So I'm going to cover this up, I'm going to
pop this in the fridge for a few hours and
then I'll show you when it goes on the grill.

My chicken was on the grill for about three
to four minutes on each side, you just have

to keep an eye on the thickness of your chicken,
you want to make sure that it doesn't overcook.

And now I want to show you how I am going
to serve it because I think it makes this

really special and I think if you've got people
coming over last minute and you don't want

to make a big production and make a bunch
of different courses, I think you can make

just this, serve it with some warm pita, maybe
a glass of chilled white wine and it would
be perfection.

I love picky foods like antipasti, something
like that I love it.

So let me show you what I've got here on my
board.

I've got some beautiful tomatoes, I've got
hummus, I've got chunks of really good feta,

cucumbers, I've got olives, I've got a little
pepperoncini, and I just sprinkled them with

some dill, salt and pepper, really really
excellent quality extra virgin olive oil and

I also have some tzatziki as well, which I
love to serve with the chicken.

You can do this with pita, you can put all
of this on top of a salad, but I think that

the entire thing together is absolutely a
money maker and everybody would love it, and

you could feed a lot of people on a pound
and a half of chicken, which is always a bonus
in my opinion.
I mean the chicken is so, look how juicy.
Right?
It's so perfectly cooked.
It tastes like a million and a half bucks.
That's a number.

And it's everything that you want from a good
grilled chicken.
Minimal effort.
Maximum pleasure.
Maximum flavor.

And that is what I am all about, especially
around this time of year where you've got

people dropping over unannounced a lot and
you want to make something really delicious

and really easy, and you don't want to make
yourself crazy, and these are also things

that you can have on hand as well, use some
store bought hummus, use store bought tzatziki
if you want to.

But I think that is pretty perfect, scatter
some lemon wedges around because I personally

really love that with dill and cucumber and
tomato and chicken, phenomenal.

You've got a dinner that everybody will remember,
hopefully they don't remember it too well
because they'll come over the next night.
Ha ha!
I'm going to take this piece of chicken.

LauraintheKitchen.com for the written recipe,
hope you enjoyed spending time with me, I'll
see you next time.
Bye!
